security_audit.summary: All 309 static findings are false positives. The scanner misidentifies hex color codes (#E69F00, etc.) as cryptographic hashes, markdown code blocks as shell execution, and configuration variables as certificate files. This is a legitimate scientific visualization library with matplotlib styling, color palettes, and figure export utilities. No actual security risks exist - the skill only manipulates local figure files and contains no network calls, external commands, or credential handling.

content.value_statement: Scientific visualization transforms data into clear, accurate figures for publication. This skill ensures your figures meet journal standards while being accessible to all readers, including those with color blindness.
actual_capabilities: Generate publication-ready figures with proper DPI and vector formats
Apply journal-specific styling for Nature, Science, Cell, PLOS, and IEEE
Create multi-panel figures with consistent styling
Add statistical annotations and error bars correctly
Export figures in PDF, EPS, SVG, TIFF, and PNG formats
limitations: Requires matplotlib, seaborn, and plotly installations
Focused on 2D static figures for print publication
Journal specifications should be verified before submission

prompt_templates.title: Basic Publication Plot
prompt_templates.scenario: Create a simple line plot for a paper
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a publication-quality line plot of my data with error bars, proper labels with units, and save as PDF. Use the Okabe-Ito color palette for accessibility.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Panel Figure
prompt_templates.scenario: Combine multiple plots into one figure
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a 4-panel figure (2x2 layout) comparing different experimental conditions. Label panels A-D, use consistent styling, and ensure the figure fits Nature's single column width.

prompt_templates.title: Statistical Comparison
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a box plot comparing three treatment groups with individual data points overlaid. Add significance markers and use colorblind-safe colors. Include sample sizes.

prompt_templates.title: Journal-Specific Formatting
prompt_templates.prompt: Configure matplotlib for Cell journal requirements and create a heatmap with proper colormap. Ensure the figure meets their dimension and font requirements.

Added error bars showing 95% confidence intervals
Set font to Arial 8pt for labels, 6pt for tick labels
Saved as both PDF (vector) and PNG (300 DPI) formats
Figure includes individual data points with jitter for transparency

output: Configured figure at 183mm width for double-column publication

Applied consistent Okabe-Ito colors across all panels

best_practices: Always test figures in grayscale to ensure accessibility without color
Include sample sizes (n) and error bar definitions in figure captions
Use vector formats (PDF, EPS) for plots; use TIFF only for images
anti_patterns: Never use JPEG format for scientific figures - it creates compression artifacts
Avoid red-green color combinations that are invisible to 8% of men with color blindness
Do not use 3D effects or unnecessary decorations that distort data perception

faq.question: What file format should I use for my figures?
faq.answer: Use vector formats (PDF or EPS) for plots and graphs. Use TIFF or PNG for microscopy images. Never use JPEG for scientific figures.

faq.question: How do I ensure my figures are colorblind-friendly?
faq.answer: Use the built-in Okabe-Ito palette, test figures in grayscale, and add redundant encoding like line styles or markers.

faq.question: What is the minimum font size for publication figures?
faq.answer: At final print size, use minimum 7-9 pt for axis labels and 6-8 pt for tick labels. Arial or Helvetica work best.

faq.question: How do I create multi-panel figures?
faq.answer: Use matplotlib GridSpec for flexible layouts, label panels with bold letters, and ensure consistent styling across panels.

faq.question: Can I use this for any journal?
faq.answer: Yes, includes configurations for Nature, Science, Cell, PLOS, ACS, and IEEE. Custom dimensions can be set for other journals.

faq.question: What statistical information should I include?
faq.answer: Always show error bars (specify SD, SEM, or CI), include sample sizes (n), and mark statistical significance clearly.
